pagination-offset.description: Offset from which to return the next set of resources. Use the value of the 'offset' field from the response of a list operation as input here to paginate through all the resources
pagination-offset.name: offset

pagination-size.description: Number of resources to be returned.
pagination-size.name: size

pagination-tags-filter.description: A list of tags to filter the list of resources on. Multiple tags can be concatenated using ',' to mean AND or using '/' to mean OR.
pagination-tags-filter.name: tags

service_id.name: service_id
service_id.description: ID **or** name of the service to lookup

certificate_id.name: certificate_id
certificate_id.description: The unique identifier of the Certificate to retrieve.

certificate_name_or_id.name: certificate_name_or_id
certificate_name_or_id.description: The unique identifier or the `name` attribute of the Certificate whose SNIs are to be retrieved. When using this endpoint, only SNIs associated to the specified Certificate will be listed.

sni_id.name: sni_id
sni_id.description: The unique identifier or the name of the SNI to retrieve.

consumer_id.name: consumer_id
consumer_id.description: The unique identifier or the username of the Consumer to retrieve.

plugin_id_or_instance_name.name: plugin_id_or_instance_name
plugin_id_or_instance_name.description: The unique identifier of the Plugin to create or update.

key-set_id_or_name.name: key-set_id_or_name
key-set_id_or_name.description: The unique identifier or the `name` attribute of the Key Set that should be associated to the newly-created Key.

key_id_or_name.name: key_id_or_name
key_id_or_name.description: The unique identifier or the name of the Key to retrieve.

upstream_id.name: upstream_id
upstream_id.description: The unique identifier of the Upstream associated to the Certificate to be retrieved.

target_id.name: target_id
target_id.description: The `id` of an existing target entry.

vault_id_or_prefix.name: vault_id_or_prefix
vault_id_or_prefix.description: The unique identifier or the prefix of the Vault to retrieve.

tag.name: tags
tag.description: Tags are strings associated to entities in Kong.

log_level.name: log_level
log_level.description: Log levels are set in Kongâ€™s configuration. Log levels increase in order of their severity

runtime_group_id.name: runtime_group_id
runtime_group_id.description: The ID of your runtime group. This variable is available in the Konnect manager

runtimeGroupId.name: runtimeGroupId
runtimeGroupId.description: The ID of your runtime group. This variable is available in the Konnect manager

route_id.name: route_id
route_id.description: The unique identifier or the name of the route to retrieve.

group_id.name: group_id
group_id.description: The UUID of the consumer group.

page_size.name: page_size
page_size.description: The number of items to include in a page.

page_number.name: page_number
page_number.description: The specific page number in the collection results.

CA-Certificate.description: A CA certificate object represents a trusted CA. These objects are used by Kong to verify the validity of a client or server certificate. CA Certificates can be both tagged and filtered by tags.
CA-Certificate.title: CA-Certificate

cert.description: PEM-encoded public certificate of the CA.

cert_digest.description: SHA256 hex digest of the public certificate.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resouce was updated.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Certificate for grouping and filtering.

Certificate.description: A certificate object represents a public certificate. These fields are _referenceable_, and can be stored as [secrets](http://docs.konqhq.com/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/getting-started) in a vault. References must follow a [specific format](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/reference-format).
Certificate.title: Certificate

cert.description: PEM-encoded public certificate chain of the SSL key This field is referenceable and can be stored in a vault. References must follow a [specific format](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/reference-format).

cert_alt.description: PEM-encoded public certificate chain of the alternate SSL key pair. This should only be set if you have both RSA and ECDSA types of certificate available and would like Kong to prefer serving using ECDSA certs.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resouce was updated.

id.description: The UUID representation of the certificate object.

key.description: PEM-encoded private key of the SSL key pair. This field is _referenceable_, which means it can be securely stored as a [secret](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/getting-started) in a vault. References must follow a [specific format](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/reference-format).

key_alt.description: PEM-encoded private key of the alternate SSL key pair. This should only be set if you have both RSA and ECDSA types of certificate available and would like Kong to prefer serving using ECDSA certs when client advertises support for it. This field is _referenceable_, which means it can be securely stored as a [secret](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/getting-started) in a vault. References must follow a [specific format](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/reference-format).

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Certificate for grouping and filtering.

Consumer.description: The Consumer object represents a consumer - or a user - of a service. You can either rely on Kong as the primary datastore, or you can map the consumer list with your database to keep consistency between Kong and your existing primary datastore.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resouce was updated.

custom_id.description: Field for storing an existing unique ID for the Consumer - useful for mapping Kong with users in your existing database. You must send either this field or `username` with the request.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Consumer for grouping and filtering.

username.description: The unique username of the Consumer. You must send either this field or `custom_id` with the request.

Consumer.title: Consumer

Key.description: A Key object holds a representation of asymmetric keys in various formats. When Kong or a Kong plugin requires a specific public or private key to perform certain operations, it can use this entity.
Key.title: Key

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

id.description: The unique identifier or the prefix of the Vault to delete.

jwk.description: A JSON Web Key represented as a string.

kid.description: A unique identifier for a key.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resouce was updated.

set.description: The id (an UUID) of the key-set with which to associate the key.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Key for grouping and filtering.

Key-set.title: Key-set
Key-set.description: A Key Set object holds a collection of asymmetric key objects. This entity allows to logically group keys by their purpose.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

id.description: The unique identifier or the name of the Key to delete.

name.description: The name to associate with the given key-set.

tags.description: n optional set of strings associated with the Key for grouping and filtering

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last updated.

Plugin.description: A Plugin entity represents a plugin configuration that will be executed during the HTTP request/response lifecycle.

config.description: The configuration properties for the Plugin which can be found on the plugins documentation page in the [Kong Hub](https://docs.konghq.com/hub/).

consumer.description: If set, the plugin will activate only for requests where the specified has been authenticated. (Note that some plugins can not be restricted to consumers this way.). Leave unset for the plugin to activate regardless of the authenticated Consumer.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

name.description: The name of the Plugin that's going to be added. Currently, the Plugin must be installed in every Kong instance separately.

protocols.description: A list of the request protocols that will trigger this plugin. The default value, as well as the possible values allowed on this field, may change depending on the plugin type. For example, plugins that only work in stream mode will only support `tcp` and `tls`.

route.description: If set, the plugin will only activate when receiving requests via the specified route. Leave unset for the plugin to activate regardless of the route being used.

service.description: If set, the plugin will only activate when receiving requests via one of the routes belonging to the specified service. Leave unset for the plugin to activate regardless of the service being matched.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Plugin for grouping and filtering.

Plugin.title: Plugin

Route.description: Route entities define rules to match client requests. Every request matching a given route will be proxied to its associated service.
Route.title: Route

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

destinations.description: A list of IP destinations of incoming connections that match this route when using stream routing. Each entry is an object with fields ip (optionally in CIDR range notation) and/or port.

headers.description: One or more lists of values indexed by header name that will cause this route to match if present in the request. The `Host` header cannot be used with this attribute: hosts should be specified using the `hosts` attribute. When `headers` contains only one value and that value starts with the special prefix `~*`, the value is interpreted as a regular expression.

hosts.description: A list of domain names that match this route. Note that the hosts value is case sensitive.

https_redirect_status_code.description: The status code Kong responds with when all properties of a route match except the protocol i.e. if the protocol of the request is `HTTP` instead of `HTTPS`. `Location` header is injected by Kong if the field is set to 301, 302, 307 or 308. Note: This config applies only if the route is configured to only accept the `https` protocol.

methods.description: A list of HTTP methods that match this route.

name.description: The name of the route. Route names must be unique, and they are case sensitive. For example, there can be two different routes named test and Test.

path_handling.description: Controls how the service path, route path and requested path are combined when sending a request to the upstream. See above for a detailed description of each behavior.

paths.description: A list of paths that match this route.

preserve_host.description: When matching a route via one of the `hosts` domain names, use the request `Host` header in the upstream request headers. If set to `false`, the upstream `Host` header will be that of the service's `host`.

protocols.description: An array of the protocols this route should allow. See the [route Object](#route-object) section for a list of accepted protocols. When set to only `https`, HTTP requests are answered with an upgrade error. When set to only `http`, HTTPS requests are answered with an error.

regex_priority.description: A number used to choose which route resolves a given request when several routes match it using regexes simultaneously. When two routes match the path and have the same `regex_priority`, the older one (lowest `created_at`) is used. Note that the priority for non-regex routes is different (longer non-regex routes are matched before shorter ones).

request_buffering.description: Whether to enable request body buffering or not. With HTTP 1.1, it may make sense to turn this off on services that receive data with chunked transfer encoding.

response_buffering.description: Whether to enable response body buffering or not. With HTTP 1.1, it may make sense to turn this off on services that send data with chunked transfer encoding.

service.description: The service this route is associated to. This is where the route proxies traffic to.

snis.description: A list of SNIs that match this route when using stream routing.

sources.description: A list of IP sources of incoming connections that match this route when using stream routing. Each entry is an object with fields ip (optionally in CIDR range notation) and/or port.

strip_path.description: When matching a route via one of the `paths`, strip the matching prefix from the upstream request URL.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the route for grouping and filtering.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last updated.

SNI.description: An SNI object represents a many-to-one mapping of hostnames to a certificate. That is, a certificate object can have many hostnames associated with it; when Kong receives an SSL request, it uses the SNI field in the Client Hello to lookup the certificate object based on the SNI associated with the certificate.

certificate.description: The id (a UUID) of the certificate with which to associate the SNI hostname. The Certificate must have a valid private key associated with it to be used by the SNI object.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

name.description: The SNI name to associate with the given certificate.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the SNIs for grouping and filtering.

Service.description: service entities are abstractions of upstream services. The main attribute of a service is its URL which can be set as a single string or by specifying the `protocol`, `host`, `port` and `path` individually.

ca_certificates.description: Array of `CA Certificate` object UUIDs that are used to build the trust store while verifying upstream server's TLS certificate. If set to `null` when Nginx default is respected. If default CA list in Nginx are not specified and TLS verification is enabled, then handshake with upstream server will always fail (because no CA are trusted).

client_certificate.description: Certificate to be used as client certificate while TLS handshaking to the upstream server.

connect_timeout.description: The timeout in milliseconds for establishing a connection to the upstream server.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

enabled.description: Whether the service is active. If set to `false`, the proxy behavior will be as if any routes attached to it do not exist (404). Default: `true`.

host.description: The host of the upstream server. Note that the host value is case sensitive.

name.description: The service name.

path.description: The path to be used in requests to the upstream server.

protocol.description: The protocol used to communicate with the upstream.

read_timeout.description: The timeout in milliseconds between two successive read operations for transmitting a request to the upstream server.

retries.description: The number of retries to execute upon failure to proxy.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the service for grouping and filtering.

tls_verify.description: Whether to enable verification of upstream server TLS certificate. If set to `null`, then the Nginx default is respected.

tls_verify_depth.description: Maximum depth of chain while verifying Upstream server's TLS certificate. If set to `null`, then the Nginx default is respected.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last updated.

url.description: Helper field to set `protocol`, `host`, `port` and `path` using a URL. This field is write-only and is not returned in responses.

write_timeout.description: The timeout in milliseconds between two successive write operations for transmitting a request to the upstream server.

Service.title: Service

Target.description: A target is an ip address/hostname with a port that identifies an instance of a backend service. Every upstream can have many targets, and the targets can be dynamically added, modified, or deleted. Changes take effect on the fly. To disable a target, post a new one with `weight=0`; alternatively, use the `DELETE` convenience method to accomplish the same. The current target object definition is the one with the latest `created_at`.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last updated.

id.description: The unique identifier or the name of the upstream for which to update the target.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Target for grouping and filtering.

target.description: The target address (ip or hostname) and port. If the hostname resolves to an SRV record, the `port` value will be overridden by the value from the DNS record.

upstream.description: The unique identifier or the name of the upstream for which to update the target.

weight.description: The weight this target gets within the upstream loadbalancer (`0`-`65535`). If the hostname resolves to an SRV record, the `weight` value will be overridden by the value from the DNS record.

Upstream.description: The upstream object represents a virtual hostname and can be used to loadbalance incoming requests over multiple services (targets). So for example an upstream named `service.v1.xyz` for a service object whose `host` is `service.v1.xyz`. Requests for this service would be proxied to the targets defined within the upstream. An upstream also includes a [health checker][healthchecks], which is able to enable and disable targets based on their ability or inability to serve requests. The configuration for the health checker is stored in the upstream object, and applies to all of its targets.

algorithm.description: Which load balancing algorithm to use.

client_certificate.description: If set, the certificate to be used as client certificate while TLS handshaking to the upstream server.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resouce was updated.

hash_fallback.description: What to use as hashing input if the primary `hash_on` does not return a hash (eg. header is missing, or no Consumer identified). Not available if `hash_on` is set to `cookie`.

hash_fallback_header.description: The header name to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_fallback` is set to `header`.

hash_fallback_query_arg.description: The name of the query string argument to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_fallback` is set to `query_arg`.

hash_fallback_uri_capture.description: The name of the route URI capture to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_fallback` is set to `uri_capture`.

hash_on.description: What to use as hashing input. Using `none` results in a weighted-round-robin scheme with no hashing.

hash_on_cookie.description: The cookie name to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` or `hash_fallback` is set to `cookie`. If the specified cookie is not in the request, Kong will generate a value and set the cookie in the response.

hash_on_cookie_path.description: The cookie path to set in the response headers. Only required when `hash_on` or `hash_fallback` is set to `cookie`.

hash_on_header.description: The header name to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` is set to `header`.

hash_on_query_arg.description: The name of the query string argument to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` is set to `query_arg`.

hash_on_uri_capture.description: The name of the route URI capture to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` is set to `uri_capture`.

host_header.description: The hostname to be used as `Host` header when proxying requests through Kong.

name.description: This is a hostname, which must be equal to the `host` of a service.

slots.description: The number of slots in the load balancer algorithm. If `algorithm` is set to `round-robin`, this setting determines the maximum number of slots. If `algorithm` is set to `consistent-hashing`, this setting determines the actual number of slots in the algorithm. Accepts an integer in the range `10`-`65536`.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Upstream for grouping and filtering.

use_srv_name.description: If set, the balancer will use SRV hostname(if DNS Answer has SRV record) as the proxy upstream `Host`.

Vault.description: Vault entities are used to configure different Vault connectors. Examples of Vaults are Environment Variables, Hashicorp Vault and AWS Secrets Manager. Configuring a Vault allows referencing the secrets with other entities. For example a certificate entity can store a reference to a certificate and key, stored in a vault, instead of storing the certificate and key within the entity. This allows a proper separation of secrets and configuration and prevents secret sprawl.

config.description: The configuration properties for the Vault which can be found on the vaults' documentation page.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

description.description: The description of the Vault entity.
description.example: This vault is used to retrieve redis database access credentials

name.description: The name of the Vault that's going to be added. Currently, the Vault implementation must be installed in every Kong instance.

prefix.description: The unique prefix (or identifier) for this Vault configuration. The prefix is used to load the right Vault configuration and implementation when referencing secrets with the other entities.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Vault for grouping and filtering.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last updated.

Example Vault.name: env
Example Vault.description: This vault is used to retrieve redis database access credentials

pagination-offset-response.description: Offset is used to paginate through the API. Provide this value to the next list operation to fetch the next page

cert.description: PEM-encoded public certificate of the CA.

cert_digest.description: SHA256 hex digest of the public certificate.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Certificate for grouping and filtering.

CA-cert-request.description: This request body represents a new Certificate Authority (CA) certificate and includes the properties required to create a new certificate.

cert.description: PEM-encoded public certificate chain of the SSL key pair.

key.description: PEM-encoded private key of the SSL key pair.

cert_alt.description: PEM-encoded public certificate chain of the alternate SSL key pair.

key_alt.description: PEM-encoded private key of the alternate SSL key pair.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Certificate for grouping and filtering.

name.description: The SNI name to associate with the given certificate.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the SNIs for grouping and filtering.

certificate.description: The id (a UUID) of the certificate with which to associate the SNI hostname. The Certificate must have a valid private key associated with it to be used by the SNI object. With form-encoded, the notation is `certificate.id=<certificate id>`. With JSON, use `â€œcertificate:{id:<certificate id>â€}`.

create-sni.description: A JSON object containing the details of the new SNI, including the name, certificate, and tags.

username.description: The unique username of the Consumer. You must send either this field or custom_id with the request.

custom_id.description: Field for storing an existing unique ID for the Consumer - useful for mapping Kong with users in your existing database. You must send either this field or username with the request.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Consumer for grouping and filtering.

name.description: The name of the Plugin thatâ€™s going to be added. Currently, the Plugin must be installed in every Kong instance separately.

route.description: If set, the plugin will only activate when receiving requests via the specified route. Leave unset for the plugin to activate regardless of the route being used. Default: `null`.With form-encoded, the notation is `route.id=<route id> or route.name=<route name>`. With JSON, use `route:{id:<route id>}` or `route:{name:<route name>}`.

service.description: If set, the plugin will only activate when receiving requests via one of the routes belonging to the specified service.

config.description: The configuration properties for the Plugin

protocols.description: A list of the request protocols that will trigger this plugin.

enabled.description: Whether the plugin is applied. Default: `true`.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Plugin for grouping and filtering.

name.description: The name to associate with the given key-set.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Key for grouping and filtering.

set.description: The id (an UUID) of the key-set with which to associate the key .With form-encoded, the notation is `set.id=<set id>` or `set.name=<set name>`. With JSON, use `â€œset:{id:<set id>}` or `set:{name:<set name>}.`

name.description: The name to associate with the given keys.

kid.description: A unique identifier for a key.

jwk.description: A JSON Web Key represented as a string.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Key for grouping and filtering.

name.description: The name of the route. Route names must be unique, and they are case sensitive. For example, there can be two different routes named â€œtestâ€ and â€œTestâ€.

protocols.description: An array of the protocols this route should allow

methods.description: A list of HTTP methods that match this route.

hosts.description: A list of domain names that match this route. Note that the hosts value is case sensitive. With form-encoded, the notation is `hosts[]=example.com&hosts[]=foo.test`. With JSON, use an Array.

paths.description: A list of paths that match this route. With form-encoded, the notation is `paths[]=/foo&paths[]=/bar`. With JSON, use an array. The path can be a regular expression, or a plain text pattern.

headers.description: One or more lists of values indexed by header name that will cause this route to match if present in the request. The Host header cannot be used with this attribute: hosts should be specified using the `hosts` attribute. When headers contains only one value and that value starts with the special prefix` ~*`, the value is interpreted as a regular expression.

https_redirect_status_code.description:
The status code Kong responds with when all properties of a route match except the protocol i.e. if the protocol of the request is `HTTP` instead of `HTTPS`
Location header is injected by Kong if the field is set to `301`, `302`, `307` or `308`. Note: This config applies only if the route is configured to only accept the https protocol. Accepted values are: `426`, `301`, `302`, `307`, `308`. Default: `426`.

regex_priority.description: A number used to choose which route resolves a given request when several routes match it using regexes simultaneously. When two routes match the path and have the same regex_priority, the older one (lowest `created_at`) is used. Note that the priority for non-regex routes is different (longer non-regex routes are matched before shorter ones). Default: `0`.

strip_path.description: When matching a route via one of the paths, strip the matching prefix from the upstream request URL. Default: `true`.

path_handling.description: Controls how the service path, route path and requested path are combined when sending a request to the upstream. Accepted values are: `v0`, `v1`. Default: `v0`.

preserve_host.description: When matching a route via one of the `hosts` domain names, use the request `host` header in the upstream request headers. If set to `false`, the upstream Host header will be that of the serviceâ€™s host.

request_buffering.description: Whether to enable request body buffering or not. With HTTP 1.1, it may make sense to turn this off on services that receive data with chunked transfer encoding. Default: true.

response_buffering.description: Whether to enable response body buffering or not. With HTTP 1.1, it may make sense to turn this off on services that send data with chunked transfer encoding. Default: `true`.

snis.description: A list of SNIs that match this route when using stream routing.

sources.description: A list of IP sources of incoming connections that match this route when using stream routing. Each entry is an object with fields â€œipâ€ (optionally in CIDR range notation) and/or â€œportâ€.

destinations.description: A list of IP destinations of incoming connections that match this route when using stream routing. Each entry is an object with fields â€œipâ€ (optionally in CIDR range notation) and/or â€œportâ€.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the route for grouping and filtering.

service.description: The service this route is associated to. This is where the route proxies traffic to. With form-encoded, the notation is service.id=<service id> or service.name=<service name>. With JSON, use â€œ`service:{id:<service id>}` or `service:{name:<service name>}`.

name.description: The service name.

retries.description: The number of retries to execute upon failure to proxy. Default:`5`.

protocol.description:
The protocol used to communicate with the upstream. Accepted values are: `grpc`, `grpcs`, `http`, `https`, `tcp`, `tls`, `tls_passthrough`, `udp`, `ws` 
, `wss` 
. Default: `http`.

host.description: The host of the upstream server. Note that the host value is case sensitive.

path.description: The path to be used in requests to the upstream server.

connect_timeout.description: The timeout in milliseconds for establishing a connection to the upstream server. Default: `60000`.

write_timeout.description: The timeout in milliseconds between two successive write operations for transmitting a request to the upstream server. Default: `60000`.

read_timeout.description: The timeout in milliseconds between two successive read operations for transmitting a request to the upstream server. Default: `60000`.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the service for grouping and filtering.

client_certificate.description: Certificate to be used as client certificate while TLS handshaking to the upstream server. With form-encoded, the notation is `client_certificate.id=<client_certificate id>`. With JSON, use `client_certificate:{id:<client_certificate id>}`.

tls_verify.description: Whether to enable verification of upstream server TLS certificate. If set to null, then the Nginx default is respected.

tls_verify_depth.description: Maximum depth of chain while verifying Upstream serverâ€™s TLS certificate. If set to null, then the Nginx default is respected. Default: null.

ca_certificates.description: Array of CA Certificate object UUIDs that are used to build the trust store while verifying upstream serverâ€™s TLS certificate. If set to null when Nginx default is respected. With form-encoded, the notation is `ca_certificates[]=4e3ad2e4-0bc4-4638-8e34-c84a417ba39b&ca_certificates[]=51e77dc2-8f3e-4afa-9d0e-0e3bbbcfd515`. With JSON, use an Array.

enabled.description: Whether the service is active. If set to `false`, the proxy behavior will be as if any routes attached to it do not exist (404). Default: `true`.

name.description: This is a hostname, which must be equal to the `host` of a service.

algorithm.description: Which load balancing algorithm to use. Accepted values are: `consistent-hashing`, `least-connections`,` round-robin`. Default: `round-robin`.

hash_on.description: What to use as hashing input. Using none results in a weighted-round-robin scheme with no hashing

hash_fallback.description: What to use as hashing input if the primary hash_on does not return a hash (eg. header is missing, or no Consumer identified). Not available if hash_on is set to cookie.

hash_on_header.description: The header name to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` is set to header.

hash_fallback_header.description: The header name to take the value from as hash input. Only required when hash_fallback is set to header.

hash_on_cookie.description: The cookie name to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` or `hash_fallback` is set to `cookie`. If the specified cookie is not in the request, Kong will generate a value and set the cookie in the response.

hash_on_cookie_path.description: The cookie path to set in the response headers. Only required when `hash_on` or `hash_fallback` is set to `cookie`. Default: `/`.

hash_on_query_arg.description: The name of the query string argument to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` is set to `query_arg`.

hash_fallback_query_arg.description: The name of the query string argument to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_fallback` is set to `query_arg`.

hash_on_uri_capture.description: The name of the route URI capture to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_on` is set to `uri_capture`.

hash_fallback_uri_capture.description: The name of the route URI capture to take the value from as hash input. Only required when `hash_fallback` is set to `uri_capture`.

slots.description: The number of slots in the load balancer algorithm. If the algorithm is set to `round-robin`, this setting determines the maximum number of slots. If the algorithm is set to `consistent-hashing`, this setting determines the actual number of slots in the algorithm. Accepts an integer in the range 10-65536.

type.description: Whether to perform passive health checks interpreting HTTP/HTTPS statuses, or just check for TCP connection success. In passive checks, http and https options are equivalent. Accepted values are: `tcp`, `http`, `https`, `grpc`, `grpcs`.

http_statuses.description: An array of HTTP statuses which represent healthiness when produced by proxied traffic, as observed by passive health checks.  With form-encoded, the notation is `http_statuses[]=200&http_statuses[]=201`. With JSON, use an array.

successes.description: Number of successes in proxied traffic (as defined by `healthchecks.passive.healthy.http_statuses`) to consider a target healthy, as observed by passive health checks.

http_statuses.description: An array of HTTP statuses which represent unhealthiness when produced by proxied traffic, as observed by passive health checks. With form-encoded, the notation is `http_statuses[]=429&http_statuses[]=500`. With JSON, use an array.

timeouts.description: Number of timeouts in proxied traffic to consider a target unhealthy, as observed by passive health checks.

http_failures.description: Number of HTTP failures in proxied traffic (as defined by `healthchecks.passive.unhealthy.http_statuses`) to consider a target unhealthy, as observed by passive health checks.

tcp_failures.description: Number of TCP connection failures to consider a target unhealthy, as observed by passive health checks.

http_statuses.description: An array of HTTP statuses to consider a success, indicating healthiness, when returned by a probe in active health checks. With form-encoded, the notation is `http_statuses[]=200&http_statuses[]=302`. With JSON, use an array.

successes.description: Number of successes in active probes (as defined by `healthchecks.active.healthy.http_statuses`) to consider a target healthy.

interval.description: Interval between active health checks for healthy targets (in seconds). A value of zero indicates that active probes for healthy targets should not be performed.

http_failures.description: Number of HTTP failures in active probes (as defined by `healthchecks.active.unhealthy.http_statuses`) to consider a target unhealthy.

http_statuses.description: An array of HTTP statuses to consider a failure, indicating unhealthiness, when returned by a probe in active health checks. With form-encoded, the notation is `http_statuses[]=429&http_statuses[]=404`. With JSON, use an array.

timeouts.description: Number of timeouts in active probes to consider a target unhealthy.

tcp_failures.description: Number of TCP failures in active probes to consider a target unhealthy.

interval.description: Interval between active health checks for unhealthy targets (in seconds). A value of zero indicates that active probes for unhealthy targets should not be performed.

type.description: Whether to perform active health checks using HTTP or HTTPS, or just attempt a TCP connection.

concurrency.description: Number of targets to check concurrently in active health checks.

timeout.description: Socket timeout for active health checks (in seconds).

http_path.description: Path to use in GET HTTP request to run as a probe on active health checks.

https_sni.description: The hostname to use as an SNI (Server Name Identification) when performing active health checks using HTTPS. This is particularly useful when Targets are configured using IPs, so that the target hostâ€™s certificate can be verified with the proper SNI.

threshold.description: The minimum percentage of the upstreamâ€™s targetsâ€™ weight that must be available for the whole upstream to be considered healthy.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Upstream for grouping and filtering.

host_header.description: The hostname to be used as Host header when proxying requests through Kong.

client_certificate.description: If set, the certificate to be used as client certificate while TLS handshaking to the upstream server.

x-my-header.description: The value(s) of the x-my-header header.

x-another-header.description: The value(s) of the x-another-header header.

upstream.description: The unique identifier or the name of the upstream for which to update the target.

id.description: The unique identifier or the name of the upstream for which to update the target.

weight.description: The weight this target gets within the upstream loadbalancer (`0`-`65535`). If the hostname resolves to an SRV record, the `weight` value will be overridden by the value from the DNS record.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Target for grouping and filtering.

Example 1.name: env
Example 1.description: This vault is used to retrieve redis database access credentials

prefix.description: The unique prefix (or identifier) for this Vault configuration. The prefix is used to load the right Vault configuration and implementation when referencing secrets with the other entities.

name.description: The name of the Vault thatâ€™s going to be added. Currently, the Vault implementation must be installed in every Kong instance.

description.description: The description of the Vault object.
description.example: This vault is used to retrieve redis database access credentials

config.description: The configuration properties for the Vault which can be found on the vaultsâ€™ documentation page.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Vault for grouping and filtering.

value.name: env
value.description: This vault is used to retrieve redis database access credentials

name.description: A unique name for the consumer group you want to create.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the consumer group for grouping and filtering.

cert.description: JSON escaped string of the certificate.

create-dp-client-cert.description: Request body for creating a dp-client-certificate.

id.description: The unique identifier or the name attribute of the Certificate whose SNIs are to be retrieved. When using this endpoint, only SNIs associated to the specified Certificate will be listed.

name.description: The SNI name to associate with the given certificate.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the SNIs for grouping and filtering.

certificate.description: The id (a UUID) of the certificate with which to associate the SNI hostname. The Certificate must have a valid private key associated with it to be used by the SNI object.

id.description: The unique identifier or the name attribute of the Certificate whose SNIs

next.description: Offset is used to paginate through the API. Provide this value to the next list operation to fetch the next page

id.description: The unique identifier or the name attribute of the consumer.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

username.description: The unique username of the consumer. You must send either this field or` custom_i`d with the request.

custom_id.description: Field for storing an existing unique ID for the Consumer - useful for mapping Kong with users in your existing database.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Consumer for grouping and filtering.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

custom_id.description: Field for the unique consumer ID

id.description: The unique id of the consumer.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Consumer for grouping and filtering.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was updated.

username.description: The unique username of the consumer.

name.description: The name of the Plugin thatâ€™s going to be added. Currently, the Plugin must be installed in every Kong instance separately.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was created.

route.description: If set, the plugin will only activate when receiving requests via the specified route. Leave unset for the plugin to activate regardless of the route being used. Default: `null`.With form-encoded, the notation is `route.id=<route id> or route.name=<route name>`. With JSON, use `route:{id:<route id>}` or `route:{name:<route name>}`.

service.description: If set, the plugin will only activate when receiving requests via one of the routes belonging to the specified service.

consumer.description: If set, the plugin will activate only for requests where the specified has been authenticated. (Note that some plugins can not be restricted to consumers this way.)

config.description: The configuration properties for the Plugin

protocols.description: A list of the request protocols that will trigger this plugin.

enabled.description: Whether the plugin is applied. Default: `true`.

tags.description: An optional set of strings associated with the Plugin for grouping and filtering.

name.description: The name to associate with the given key-set.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last created.

updated_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last updated.

tags.description: The name to associate with the given key-set.

next.description: Offset is used to paginate through the API. Provide this value to the next list operation to fetch the next page

entity_name.description: The name of the entity that corresponds to a tag

entity_id.description: The unique ID for the entity that is attached to the tag

service-response.description: The service response object is returned when creating a new service or retreiving an existing service.

created_at.description: Unix epoch when the resource was last created.

id.description: The UUID representation of the certificate object.

key.description: PEM-encoded private key of the SSL key pair. This field is _referenceable_, which means it can be securely stored as a [secret](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/getting-started) in a vault. References must follow a [specific format](/gateway/latest/plan-and-deploy/security/secrets-management/reference-format).

updated_at.description: Date the runtime group configuration was last updated.

konnectAccessToken.description:
The Konnect access token is meant to be used by the Konnect dashboard and the decK CLI to 
authenticate with.

personalAccessToken.description: The personal access token is meant to be used as an alternative to basic-auth when accessing Konnect via APIs. You can generate a Personal Access Token (PAT) from the personal access token page in the Konnect dashboard.

externalDocs.description: Documentation for Kong Gateway and its APIs

info.description: The API for configurating Konnect Runtime Groups.
info.title: Runtime Groups Configuration API

get.description: Retrieve the expected config hash for this runtime group. The expected config hash can be used to verify if the config hash of a runtime instance is up to date with the runtime group. The config hash will be the same if they are in sync.

Returns a list of pinned dataplane client certificates that are associated to this runtime group. A pinned dataplane certificate allows dataplanes configured with the certificate and corresponding private key to establish connection with this runtime group.

post.description: Pin a new DP Client Certificate to this runtime group. A pinned dataplane certificate allows dataplanes configured with the certificate and corresponding private key to establish connection with this runtime group.

get.description: Retrieve a pinned dataplane client certificate associated to this runtime group. A pinned dataplane certificate allows dataplanes configured with the certificate and corresponding private key to establish connection with this runtime group.

204.description: No Content

delete.description: Remove a pinned dataplane client certificate associated to this runtime group. Removing a pinned dataplane certificate would invalidate any dataplanes currently connected to this runtime group using this certificate.

get.description: Returns a list of runtime instance records that are associated to this runtime group. A runtime instance record contains all the metadata information of the Kong Gateway dataplane.
Retrieve a specific runtime instance record associated to this runtime group. A runtime instance record contains all the metadata information of the Kong Gateway dataplane.

204.description: No Content

delete.description: Remove a specific runtime instance record associated to this runtime group. Deleting this record does not prevent the runtime instance from re-connecting to the runtime group.

get.description: Retrieve a list of all available Certificate Authority (CA) certificates, including the certificate ID, creation date, and other details. You can use query parameters to filter the results by size or tags, for example `/ca-certificates?size=50&tags=enterprise`.

200.description: A successful response listing CA Certificates

post.description: Create a new Certificate Authority (CA) certificate. The request body must include the `cert` property, the certificate data in PEM format; it can also include `cert_digest`, a digest of the certificate in hex format for verifying the certificates integrity, and `tags`, an optional list of tags to categorize the certificate.

delete.description: Delete the specified Certificate Authority (CA) certificate using the provided ca_certificate_id.

204.description: Successfully deleted CA Certificate or the resource didn't exist

get.description: Retrieve details about the specified Certificate Authority (CA) certificate using the provided path parameter `ca_certificate_id`.

parameters.description: The unique identifier of the certificate to retrieve.
parameters.name: ca_certificate_id

200.description: The specified CA certificate exists in the system, and the response includes details about the certificate.

message.description: A message describing the error message.

put.description: Create or Update a CA Certificate using the provided path parameter `ca_certificate_id`.

get.description: Retrieve a list of all available certificate/ You can use query parameters to filter the results by size or tags, for example `/certificates?size=50&tags=enterprise`.

post.description: Create a new certificate with the provided details. Use this endpoint to add a new certificate to the system. The request body must include the certificate data and other details required for creating a new certificate.

parameters.name: runtimeGroupId
parameters.description: The ID of your runtime group. This variable is available in the Konnect manager

delete.description: Delete a Certificate

parameters.description: ID of the Certificate to delete
parameters.name: certificate_id

204.description: Successfully deleted Certificate or the resource didn't exist

get.description: Retrieve details about the specified certificate using the provided path parameter `certificate_id`.

put.description:
Update details about the specified certificate using the provided path parameter `certificate_id`.

Inserts (or replaces) the certificate under the requested `certificate_id`with the definition specified in the request body. When the `id` attribute has the structure of a UUID, the certificate being inserted/replaced will be identified by its `id`. Otherwise it will be identified by the `name`.

When creating a new Certificate without specifying `id` (neither in the path or the request body), then it will be auto-generated.

parameters.name: certificate_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the Certificate to retrieve.

parameters.name: runtimeGroupId
parameters.description: The ID of your runtime group. This variable is available in the Konnect manager

get.description: Retrieve a paginated list of all SNIs associated with a certificate. Use this endpoint to retrieve a list of SNIs that are linked to a specific certificate. You can use the optional query parameters to filter the results based on specific criteria. The response will include the list of SNIs and pagination information. See the response schema for details on the expected format of the response body.
get.summary: List SNIs associated with a certificate

post.description: Create a new SNI and associate it with a certificate in the system. Use this endpoint to add a new SNI to the system and link it to a specific certificate.

messages: certificate_id (type: foreign) constraint failed for value 'a3ad71a8-6685-4b03-a101-980a953544f6':

post.summary: Create a new SNI associated with a Certificate

delete.description: Delete a an SNI associated with a a Certificate using an ID.

204.description: Successfully deleted SNI or the resource didn't exist

delete.summary: Delete a an SNI associated with a Certificate

get.description: Get an SNI associated with a Certificate using ID or name.
get.summary: Fetch an SNI associated with a certificate

put.description:
Create or Update an SNI associated with a Certificate using ID or name.

Inserts (or replaces) the SNI under the requested resource with the definition specified in the body. The SNI will be identified by the id attribute.

When the name or id attribute has the structure of a UUID, the SNI being inserted/replaced will be identified by its id. Otherwise it will be identified by its name.

When creating a new SNI without specifying id (neither in the URL nor in the body), then it will be auto-generated.
put.summary: Upsert an SNI associated with a certificate

get.description: Retrieve a list of all consumers.You can use query parameters to filter the results by size or tags, for example `/consumers?size=50&tags=enterprise`.

post.description: Create a new Consumer

delete.description: Delete a specific consumer from the system using either the consumer ID or the consumer username. This operation is irreversible and permanently removes all data associated with the specified consumer. If the consumer was deleted succesfully the endpoint will return a 204 response indicating that the resource did not exist.

204.description: Successfully deleted Consumer or the resource didn't exist

get.description: Retrieve the details of a specific consumer in the system using either the consumer ID or the consumer username. If the consumer with the specified ID or username cannot be found, the endpoint will return a 404.

put.description:
Create or Update Consumer using ID or username. The consumer will be identified via the username or id attribute.If the consumer with the specified ID or username cannot be found, the endpoint will return a 404. 

When the username or id attribute has the structure of a UUID, the Consumer being inserted/replaced will be identified by its id. Otherwise it will be identified by its username.

When creating a new Consumer without specifying id (neither in the URL nor in the body), then it will be auto-generated.

Notice that specifying a username in the URL and a different one in the request body is not allowed.

get.description: Retrieve a list of all plugins associated with a consumer.
get.summary: List all plugins associated with a consumer

post.description: Create a new Plugin associated with a Consumer
post.summary: Create a new Plugin associated with a Consumer

delete.description: Delete a a Plugin associated with a a Consumer using ID.

204.description: Successfully deleted Plugin or the resource didn't exist

delete.summary: Delete a a Plugin associated with a a Consumer

get.description: Get a Plugin associated with a Consumer using ID.
get.summary: Fetch a Plugin associated with a Consumer

put.description: Create or Update a Plugin associated with a Consumer using ID.
put.summary: Upsert a Plugin associated with a Consumer

get.description: Retrieve a list of all Key-sets in the system. A Key Set object holds a collection of asymmetric key objects. This entity allows to logically group keys by their purpose. Key Sets can be both tagged and filtered by tags.

post.description: This endpoint allows creating a new Key-set by sending a JSON object that describes the Key-set to be created.The request body must contain all the fields required to create a new Key-set.

400.description: Returned if the request contains invalid data.

delete.description: Delete a Key-set.

204.description: Successfully deleted Key-set or the resource didn't exist

get.description: This endpoint retrieves information about a specific key-set based on its ID or name.

get.description: List all Keys

post.description: This API endpoint allows you to create a new key. When the request is successful, the API will respond with a 200 status code and a JSON object that represents the newly created key. If the request is invalid, the API will respond with a `400` status code and an error message in the response body.

get.description: This endpoint allows you to list all the plugins. You can use query parameters to filter the results by size or tags, for example `/plugins?size=50&tags=enterprise`.

post.description: Create a new Plugin.

delete.description: Delete a Plugin

204.description: Successfully deleted Plugin or the resource didn't exist

get.description: Get a Plugin using ID.

put.description: Create or Update Plugin using ID.

get.description:
List all routes

route entities define rules to match client requests. Each route is associated with a service, and a service may have multiple routes associated to it. Every request matching a given route will be proxied to its associated service.

> Note: Path handling algorithms v1 was deprecated in Kong 3.0. From Kong 3.0, when router_flavor is set to expressions, route.path_handling will be unconfigurable and the path handling behavior will be v0; when router_flavor is set to traditional_compatible, the path handling behavior will be v0 regardless of the value of route.path_handling. Only router_flavor = traditional will support path_handling v1' behavior.

Add a consumer to a specific consumer group.

If you add a consumer to multiple groups:

If all groups are allowed by the Rate Limiting Advanced plugin, only the first groupâ€™s settings will apply.
Otherwise, whichever group is specified in the Rate Limiting Advanced plugin will be active.
